instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165A: What is 820-00165A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKLT_EN: What is BKLT_EN? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKLT” before “_EN”. “BKLT” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.BKL_PWM: What is BKL_PWM? BKL_PWM sets the brightness of the screen. The system will send a PWM signal to BKL_PWM pin to set brightness. If this is low, backlight voltage will boost higher than PPBUS_G3H input, but not enough to make the screen light properly..

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi

Got a no back-light unit

Backlight circuit looks good

<RESISTOR>R5117</RESISTOR> completely burned out thou, cant attach it back as both points are also burned out.
Any tips how to attach the replacement?

Closer inspection revealed that the <TRANSISTOR>Q5158</TRANSISTOR> also has damage on the <SIGNAL>CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3</SIGNAL> line

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Those have nothing to do with backlight...what voltage do you get on BKLT output? There is a great guide on the pinned posts from Louis btw

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Lot of information on the forum.
Especially 3437 and 00165 Air boards; just use search function.

Rebuild <SIGNAL>CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3</SIGNAL> trace from <TRANSISTOR>Q5158</TRANSISTOR> to SMC area.
Then solder <RESISTOR>R5117</RESISTOR> to that line and wire its other pad to nearest 3V42 point...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Thanks.
Ok, I will dig deeper with the backlight issue

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
ok

continuity between <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and A5 ball of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> 

(all voltages taken with screen connected, psu connected, no battery)

<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> 8.51V

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> voltages 
1 - 0.02v
2 - 0.02v
3 - 2.8v

4 - 8.5v
5 - 8.5v
6 - 8.5v


F7700 was ok but I shorted it while measuring voltage ( touched both the shield and the fuse - probe slipped :/ )
It had continuity before thou and no backlight so I am guessing that this wasnt the issue

Also I am getting a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, when I hold the multimeter for a few seconds it kinda drains and short goes but when checked later - it does the same (is that relevant at all?)

Still have to work on that <SIGNAL>CPU_THRMTRIP_3V3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Are you measuring resistance with power applied??? I hope not as that's a good way to mess up your multimeter...if you have 8.6 you don't have any kind of short on PPBUS. Sounds like bad LED Driver to me. <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> resistors ok?

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
That was the case. I have learned something today :)
No short now
<RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> - 300koms
<RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> - 146 kOms
Looking fine

Will replace f7700 and investigate further

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: F7700 is fine if you have 8 volts..replace the LED Driver and see what happens.

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> 8.51V"
Which pin?
Backlight output is on K pin...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/1153-johnb8812"]JohnB8812[/URL] [/B]F7700 was fine but I accidentally killed it after taking the measurement
[B][URL="https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/member/682-2informaticos"]2informaticos[/URL] [/B]PIN 2 according to the schematics, the other pin was 0v

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
"PIN 2 according to the schematics, the other pin was 0v"
According to schematic, <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> has two pins, A and K.
And is impossible to have 0V at same time with a voltage on these pins; unless diode is burnt!

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Replace F7700 again then and remeasure. If 8 volts, then replace LED Driver.

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

new f7700 in place

Is that the led driver then?

threads.message:

Also post <SIGNAL>BKL_PWM</SIGNAL>/EN voltages; LCD connected, of course...

Just thinking - was my mistake measuring it while powered on?

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Do NOT measure diode mode with power applied! Replace F7700 and just replace the driver. Wasting time measuring when you?ll know right away if it?s the chip or not replacing it...

threads.title: macbook Air 2015 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Cheers. I am such a dummy. I dont do it often enough to remember :/
